title: Can you use a regular PC for gaming or do you need a gaming PC to play? - Quora

response.answer_text: Virtually any functioning, modern computer will run any video game. Of course, however, this does not mean the game will run smoothly on the highest-settings; in fact, it may glitch and stutter at the lowest settings. If you want to determine whether a gaming PC or regular PC is superior, then that’s a different matter. You will have to take in a few considerations: What do you consider gaming? If your idea of gaming is playing Fortnite or Minecraft (or something of that caliber) then virtually any PC, or laptop will suffice. But if your idea of gaming is playing a high-end, Triple-A game (like Red Dead Redemption 2 or The Witcher 3) then a more powerful machine will be necessary.Are you buying a cheap or expensive PC? An expensive regular PC will almost certainly perform better than a cheap, second-rate gaming PC.How old is the PC? If you buy a high-end gaming computer from 2005 and compare it to a simple, modest 2020 PC, then the modern PC will undoubtedly run better (This is a bit of an extreme example, of course).To get really good value out of a gaming PC, you have to spend a lot of money and consistently game. If it’s just an occasional hobby, and you primarily use the PC for other purposes, perhaps work or school, then maybe it’s not worth it. At the end of the day, it’s really up to preference.

You don't need a huge liquid cooled gaming rig to enjoy PC games, as there are plenty of affordable and well received alternatives that will keep you and your wallet happy. That really depends on how the machine itself performs and the availability of expansion ports. Open up your computer, check how big the CPU cooler is, a beefy cooler usually indicates a machine with decent processing power, an Athlon II x3 or equivalent will do. Your machine has AGP or PCIe ports on it’s motherboard? (PCIe x1 will do if you don’t have full sized ones) AGP and PCIe ports are brown colored if your machine is from 2011 or older. or black PCIe ports with a lock at the end that resembles that one of a RAM slot if your machine is relatively new. Brown PCIe x16 ports indicate that your board supports PCIe 2.0 speeds, this is important when checking graphics cards minimum specs, the black ones that I described support PCIe 3.0 speeds.

You can play most games with a normal pc, however the performance won’t be nearly as good. Gaming PCs are optimized to the stresses inflicted by gaming, such as high graphics requirements or high memory use. So yes, you can use a normal pc for gaming, but you won’t be running Minecraft with shaders anytime soon
